comments.text:
Same in Canada. Every Citizen is issued a Provincial Health & ID Card. 
Flash it and you're in. No fee's to speak of. Everyone pays into it through 
taxes and everyone uses it eventually (cause we all get sick, most get old, 
and we'll all die someday) unless they leave the country.
Only things that aren't covered by the public system are Prescription Drugs 
and Cosmetic Surgery.
Prescription drugs are covered for all government employees and by most 
private employers through their employment contracts. If an individual 
desires further coverage for their prescription drugs, private options are 
available, but seldom used.
Granted, our population is a fraction the size of the US, but our countries 
are still comparable in many respects.
Our taxes are considerably lower then Denmark and, while our taxes are 
higher then the United States, they aren't by a significant margin and we 
get far more mileage out of said taxes through increased efficiency.

+Laura Stender Look I'm not saying I support it, or that's it's perfect. 
The idea of obamacare is, believe it or not, to better the economy. The 
idea is that if the government can get people cheap healthcare, more and 
more people would buy into it. Therefore making people who get sick or 
injured get better quicker and back to their jobs. That increases 
productivity which in turn, betters the economy. The downfalls are, other 
major health care companies are loosing members due to this. The big 'fat 
cats' that own those health care businesses want to make as much money as 
possible, and since they're loosing members, they are increasing prices to 
make up the profit. That means that the government is actually making its 
own monopoly. So Obamacare is not ALL to blame. If the owners of the other

well. I'm sorry you're in this situation! Good luck to you!

comments.text:
I agree! Can I give you an example from Canada??  Yah? Okay!  This was at 
least 15 years ago.  I worked as a pharmacists assistant (since I was 14 - 
after school job), anyway, the seniors got their meds for free. Wonderful, 
they'd load up on their aspirin, calcium, stool softeners etc... Then the 
government had to introduce a deductible.  They asked the seniors to pay 
100 dollars every August and then after that all meds were free again 
(although they did pay a reduced dispensing fee, and they were allowed to 
get a 3 month supply, so 5.95 for each med every 3 months wasn't horrible). 
The first year and sadly for at least 3 more years, the seniors were 
freaking.  Some would rather not get their important medications because it 
was too expensive, yet were in a rush to go next door for their hair 
appointment!  It seemed ludicrous that they would opt for a nice 'do' or a 
pretty blouse rather than blood pressure/cholesterol/stomach acid 
medication.  Eventually they came around, but for the first few years, 
every August I needed ulcer medication - the arguments were crazy!  Really 
what I'm saying is change is hard, some ppl see the logic immediately and 
others after much prompting eventually come around.  Health should always 
come first.  Heck, whenever I send a card to someone for a holiday I 
usually wish them good health and happiness.  
Have a good day!  Sorry for the long response, but g+ took away the 
keystroke restrictions.

+Andrew a Well, that's absolutely wrong. As the Health care index ranks 
based on: Cost per capita, efficiency, advancement, innovation and 
technological standard. USA has one of the worse and least advanced health 
cares in the western world, and there is a simple reason for it: 
Capitalism. 

I'm all for capitalism, but not when it involves health care, because it 
creates health care into a business. In America hospitals only invest in 
cheap equipment than can be used for thousands of people. Hospitals won't 
buy certain medicines or equipment's or technologies for certain illness or 
disabilities, simply because they don't effect enough people. The most 
advanced countries in the world when it comes to health care are 
commonwealth countries, as they work together for medical innovation. Hence 
why Canada and Australia are up in the top 10 list. Also, so long as you 
have to pay for healthcare, it is not in anyway "affordable". Affordable 
healthcare is free healthcare, simple as that. I can't call a country 
civilized if it sees healthcare as something to be exploited for financial 
gain as it's the most vulnerable and weak that need healthcare the most, 
but won't be able to afford it. To even try and backup the American 
healthcare system even though the facts go completely against your 
argument, probably explains why America is crashing in pretty much every 
field. The reason countries like: Britain, France, Germany, Australia and 
Canada don't have stronger economies than America, is because unlike 
America they invest the money into public sectors. Which also explains why 
these countries and most of the developed world has overtook or is 
overtaking America in: Health care, education, science, influence, 
democracy, humanitarian, crime and justice ect ect. The only thing America 
is top at is: An over sized military it doesn't need and will never fully 
use, the number of people who believe in angels and the worlds biggest 
debt. So long as America remains so capitalistic, then it will continue to 
destroy it's self. Like Abraham Lincoln said: America will never be 
destroyed from the outside. If we falter and lose our freedoms, it will be 
because we destroyed ourselves. America is just a country that war 
profiteered during the world wars and now it's extremely nationalist, 
undemocratic, extreme democratic has a crime rate higher than mount Everest 
and a wealth inequality so large it could tilt the Earths axis,

The top 20% earners in America control 40% of the wealth, the top 1% 
earners control 10% of the total American wealth, minimum wage is lower 
than most countries and it doesn't mandate maternity leave and the bottom 
20% earners and the middle class only control 0.5% of the totally market

comments.text:
+mj carollson
Health Care is NOT a right, no one is saying you can't get medical 
treatment, we are saying that we don't want to pay YOUR bills.  I don't 
want to pay higher taxes and higher premiums so Tammy in the Ghetto with 
five Bastard Children and one on the way that she can't afford to feed can 
get her " Free" Health Care.

If Health care is a right, then where does it stop? Should we be forced to 
pay your car payment as well? Or pay for your Plastic Surgery? How about 
making Tampons a right for all Woman, and we need to pay for that to, not 
just any Tampons, but the most expensive ones on the market.

Healthcare as not being a right is a FACT, not an opinion. That is the 
problem with you Liberals, you would rather do what makes you feel good at 
the end of the day than do what is right. Doing the right thing offends 
people, sometimes results in people getting hurt, or even in the most 
extreme cases results in people getting killed,  in the long run it was the 
right thing to do.

Economically we can not afford this, we need to cut Welfare/Entitlement 
programs and benefits not create more. I am not suggesting cutting 
Grandpa's medications or Medical Treatments, I am suggesting reforming 
Welfare back to what it used to be, the basic essentials for life such as 
bread, milk, eggs, water, rice, beans etc and cut steak. lobster tails, 
crab legs, shrimp, junk food, soda, cash back assistance, etc.

Welfare is supposed to support those that have worked their whole lives and 
are retired, the psychically and mentally handicapped, and help people help 
themselves by not supporting them.
Welfare State or Socialism is not economically sustainable, and it hurts 
everyone.

The reason why Health Care is so expensive is because the Government is 
involved with massive, unnecessary regulations and taxes.

Take Medications for example. It costs Pharmaceutical Companies less than 
five cents to make a pill, after regulations, taxes, red tape,etc that pill 
now costs five dollars. Everything the Government touches it raises the 
costs. But you Liberals just don't get it.

Imagine if the DMV was privately owned and there were competition. The 
costs at DMV would be cheaper, the Customer Service would be better, etc. 
Why? Because companies have to persuade you to give them your money unlike 
the Government that can take your money at gun point. There is no 
competition when it comes to the Government so you can't go to another 
government. ( well you can move to another country).

Think Universal Healthcare is so great? Everyone keeps referring to 
Canada's  Health Care as being so wonderful, well here are the facts. Yes 
you get prompt medical care for a broken arm, but lets say you need a brain 
tumor removed, or Cancer treatments. You will be put on a waiting list for 
months. Forget about getting that one on one personal care from your 
Doctor, you will be treated like a number.

How about that little problem of Supply and Demand. As is there are not 
enough Doctors to cover everyone's needs. Throw a few Million more people 
into the system, add Millions of Illegals, we now have a problem of the 
demand being high and the supply being low, which in turns raises the cost 
of Medical care which the Middle Class will have to suffer the blunt of 
paying for.

Employers now are facing these problems,  the very little that they will 
receive as a tax break for providing their employees with Health care does 
not even cover the costs. So, is it cheaper to have all their Employees go 
on Obama Care and pay the fines which in turn the Employees have to pay for 
their own insurance? Or just simply cut hours, cut pay, lay people off, not 
hire, or all of the above. This Bill in the long run will hurt the poor, 
and decimate the Middle Class by raising Health Care costs through the roof.

It's not like you can opt out of it, you have to buy it and like it or you 
will be fined. Oh, and you better hope you pay for all the insurance to 
meet the requirements even if you don't need it, if you don't you will be 
fined.
comments.author: Grendel Wolf

comments.text:
+Grendel Wolf
Clearly you need to review the definition of fact.  The existence of 
gravity is a fact.  That you will die at some point is a fact.  Your 
feeling as to whether or not healthcare being made available to all is 
advantageous or not---is an opinion.

P.S. If you really care about money as much as you claim to (hell, if you 
even take once second to think about the principle of residual loss for a 
moment) you wouldn't be so shortsighted as to say healthcare is not a 
right.  Do you have ANY idea what the costs are for emergency (and 
outpatient) treatment of ailments that are treatable for a fraction of the 
cost if addressed in the early or preventative stages?  Add to that the hit 
our nation's economic productivity takes every time a minor medical issue 
becomes a major medical issue and takes a skilled, knowledgeable worker out 
of commission---and you've got a problem.   There wasn't nearly as much a 
problem with the healthcare system as it was decades ago, but the young 
adults you are so concerned about are living in a society where 
pre-Obamacare private health insurance was scarce (and that which was 
available a mere shadow of the benefits their parents enjoyed).  They are 
living in a world where "permalancing" is the employment mode of the day, 
ever since employers realized it was better for the bottom line to treat 
people as human capital and not human beings.  Obama didn't inflict that 
bullet wound; he's just made an attempt to move us closer to stopping the 
blood loss.  Yes, it will cost us in taxes.  But that I liken it to the 
discomfort one experiences when using rubbing alcohol to disinfect a 
wound.  Besides, what he has done is far better than what most of the 
generation who stood idly by while Reaganomics chimed the beginning of the 
end can say they've accomplished. 

If you think you can do better, I hear there's an election coming up in 
2016.
